}} The 'Pittsburgh Pirates' are a Major League Baseball club based in
Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. They play in the Central Division of the National
League, and are five-time World Series champions. The Pirates are also often
referred to as the "Bucs", or sometimes the "Buccos" (derived from buccaneer, a
synonym for pirate).

The franchise joined the National League in its sixth season in 1887 and was
competitive from its early years, winning three National League titles from 1901
to 1903, playing in the very first World Series in 1903 and winning their first
World Series in 1909 behind Honus Wagner. The Pirates have had many ups and
downs during their long history, most famously winning the 1960 World Series on
a game winning homerun by Bill Mazeroski, the only time that Game 7 of the World
Series has ever ended with a home run. They also won the 1971 World Series
behind Roberto Clemente and the 1979 World Series under the slogan "We Are
Family", led by "Pops" Willie Stargell. Overall the Pirates have won five World
Series and lost two. The five that the Pirates won were all seven-game Series.
After a run of regular-season success in the early 1990s (making the NLCS three
straight years), the Pirates have struggled in recent decades, with 20
consecutive losing seasons to date, the longest in North American professional
sports history.
